s.text: Pundits rehashed the rules of succession in the event of something worse.

Other news from abroad: 1) British Prime Minister John Major announced that a new national election will be held May 1. Polls show the opposition Labor Party leading by nearly 2-to-1.

The announcement was organized by the NAACP, which suspects racism in the investigation because all the accused officers are black, and most of the accusers, white.

The announcement was organized by the NAACP, which suspects racism in the investigation because all the accused officers are black, and most of the accusers, white.

The New York Times reported that through in vitro fertilization, "tens of thousands of embryos are steadily accumulating in tanks of liquid nitrogen" in the United States, and their lives can be started at any time in the future.

Among the images reported on by the New York Times are "two hands holding up a severed head by the hair," "a man confronting his own severed head on a plate," and "a man's brain and the upper end of his spinal column ...
Post reported that a Republican House committee counsel hit up investment firms for $100,000 contributions to the GOP shortly after working on financial-deregulation legislation.
The European Union has agreed to send in a few dozen military and police advisers, but not a big force.
The European Union has agreed to send in a few dozen military and police advisers, but not a big force.

3) The New York Times reported that the administration endorsed a project in China that was financially important to the Riady family just after a Riady-controlled company put Webster Hubbell on its payroll.
3) The Washington Post reported that for $5,000, the National Republican Senatorial Committee is offering donors a chance to give Trent Lott and other senators "advice" at a forum next month.
3) The Washington Post reported that for $5,000, the National Republican Senatorial Committee is offering donors a chance to give Trent Lott and other senators "advice" at a forum next month.

Attorney General Janet Reno said she tried to tell National Security Adviser Tony Lake about the Chinese scheme 10 months ago but was unable to reach him by phone, so she asked the FBI to tell the White House, which led to the above fiasco.
